SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Joseph C. Wilson
Present Address: 4165 Skeena St., Vancouver, B.C.
Pioneer Address: 2nd Church
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1904

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that very one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember; and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)
SASKATOON ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 5
Planter Reservation and Social Life

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors on Sundays?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Any time you were in one, you were always invited. What was the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Did you ever go there just for a visit?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have parties when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe, only a year or so are held numerous gatherings & dancing at the saloon also occasionally here then.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. 1918 and on until Hall was built at Ashburn.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.) Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and entertainments? If you lived in the country, did you continue to use the school house for district gatherings, and come to our hall just for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of this hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in questions 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box seats, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, phonics, etc.)

If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, fill in dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it, the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, did you live in the country, did you continue to use your own home for district gatherings, and came to the hall for all functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 6, 7, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What songs were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Has there ever been disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Has card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who favored upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formalities or "swahili" do you remember in small towns, such as greetings and hats when calling, calling cards, matters treated ceremonially, in parties, etc.? Describe what you remember about obirave, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

13. Was the obirave known in your community? Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can show some change in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

14. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

15. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

16. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district? Tell when it was organized. Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formalizing or "awakening" do you remember in small towns, such as Groves and later when calling, calling cards, matters treated seriously by parties, etc.?

13. Has the awakening been in your community? Describe what you remember about awakenings, telling how common they were, any individuals connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of meetings, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements or not, always additional but not necessarily at parties and given approximate dates whenever you can show some change in visiting or social life became noticeable.
